body_content.explanation: to (cause to) go or do something very quickly:
examples: I've been rushing (about/around) all day trying to get everything done.
I rushed up the stairs/to the office/to find a phone.
When she turned it upside down the water rushed out.
We shouldn't rush to blame them.
You can't rush a job like this.
The emergency legislation was rushed through Parliament in a morning.
Don't rush me!
The United Nations has rushed medical aid and food to the famine zone.
He rushed the children off to school so they wouldn't be late.

body_content.explanation: If a group of people rush an enemy or the place where an enemy is, they attack suddenly and all together:
examples: We rushed the palace gates and killed the guards.

body_content.explanation: In American football, to rush is to carry the ball forward across the place on the field where play begins. Also, a member of the opposite team rushes when they force their way to the back of the field quickly to catch the player carrying the ball.
a situation in which you have to hurry or move somewhere quickly:
examples: Slow down! What's the rush?
Why is it always such a rush to get ready in the mornings?
Everyone seemed to be in a rush.
He was in a rush to get home.
They were in no rush to sell the house.

body_content.explanation: a time when a lot of things are happening or a lot of people are trying to do or get something:
examples: There's always a rush to get the best seats.
I try to do my shopping before the Christmas rush.
There's been a rush for (= sudden popular demand for) tickets.

body_content.explanation: the act of suddenly moving somewhere quickly:
examples: There was a rush of air as she opened the door.
They made a rush at him to get his gun.

body_content.explanation: a sudden movement of people to a certain area, usually because of some economic advantage:
examples: the California gold rush

body_content.explanation: in American football, an attempt to run forwards carrying the ball, or an attempt to quickly reach and stop a player from the opposing team who is carrying the ball
a sudden strong emotion or physical feeling:
examples: The memory of who he was came back to him with a rush.
I had my first cigarette for a year and felt a sudden rush (of dizziness).

body_content.explanation: a plant like grass that grows in or near water and whose long, thin, hollow stems can be dried and made into floor coverings, containers, etc.:
examples: a rush mat
